[Mr SPEAKER in the Chair]

MERGER (SINGAPORE/FEDERATION OF MALAYA)
(White Paper)


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [20th November, 1961],

    "That, whereas it has always been the avowed objective of all nationalists of Malaya to achieve the reunification of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya and to remove the artificial division created by the British by their policy of "divide and rule", this House affirms and declares that the first objective of all true patriots of Malaya is to achieve the reunification of these two territories in a merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya."-(The Minister for Labour-Inche Ahmad bin Ibrahim).

    Question again proposed.

2.32 p.m.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday I was speaking about citizenship - the issue that is going to be the nail in the coffin of the P.A.P. Unfortunately, although the vernacular Press has given a fair coverage - and a good coverage - of the issue which is so very important to every person in Singapore, the English Press has left it almost completely out. I hope in future such an important issue like citizenship would be given decent coverage, so that every person in Singapore can see both sides of the question. Only then can everybody decide properly the future for himself as well as for the whole of Singapore.

    I saw in the papers also, Sir, that they referred to my mention of the U.M.N.O. Government. Of course, that was a technical error. I really meant the Alliance Government.

Column: 356



    When the House adjourned yesterday, Sir, I was quoting the Prime Minister on his clarification of citizenship as published in the Straits Times of 26th October, 1961. The words I quoted read as follows:

    'Any Singapore citizen who wishes to live in the present Federation and become a citizen of the present Federation can apply for citizenship of the present Federation under the laws of the present Federation.'

I was saying, Sir, this innocent-looking statement covered a multitude of sins. It means, in the first place, if a Singapore citizen goes to the Federation after the P.A.P.'s phoney merger, he will become disenfranchised and will not be allowed to vote or to stand for election in the Federation. Secondly, he can get Federal citizenship rights only if he stays there for ten years in order to satisfy the necessary residential qualification, pass a Malay language test, and must be considered by the Federation Government to be of good character. You know what this means, Sir. It means that if you do not agree with the Federation Government politics, you can go and whistle for your citizenship. In short, he will be treated like any alien, although he has a so-called Federal nationality that is supposed to make him equal to the Federal citizen.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, at the present moment, so I am informed, a Singapore citizen born in Singapore, and thereby also a British subject, has the right to vote and stand for election if he goes to the United Kingdom - the colonial master's country. But - and this is the irony of it - after the P.A.P.'s phoney merger, even those who are born here will not have those rights in the Federation - our so-called partner. It is humiliating, Sir, that under this phoney merger a Singapore citizen when he goes to the Federation will receive less equality and trust than what he receives today in the country of his colonial master. Mr Speaker, Sir, the word "phoney" is indeed a gross understatement in describing this so-called merger of the P.A.P.

    There is also, Sir, another humiliating fact about the P.A.P.'s phoney merger; that is, under this phoney merger, all those persons who will be born in Singapore after the date of this phoney merger

Column: 357

will not become Federal citizens by right of birth. This is something which the P.A.P. has concealed from our people and I challenge the P.A.P. to deny this. Perhaps the Prime Minister would care to clarify the earlier clarification in order to clarify his conscience for this shameful, disreputable and unpardonable betrayal of the people.

    Let me now, Sir, discuss the differences between the term "citizen" and "national". "Citizenship" and "nationality" are two distinct concepts. "Citizenship" expresses the rights of an individual within a State, and "nationality" his rights outside the State.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Lawyer baharu!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: When the Prime Minister says that everyone is going to get something more, he means that every Singapore citizen is to become a Federal national. But what are the rights and privileges of a national? The Prime Minister has not been able to give anything more than the right to a Federal passport. In fact, there is really nothing more. I am not saying that the right to a passport is not good, but that is what every Singapore citizen today already has. To the citizen of Singapore, what difference is there whether or not he possesses the same passport as the Federation citizen? How many of our people in the first place can afford to go abroad and so need passports? Our workers, farmers and hawkers earn hardly enough to keep body and soul together, let alone have money to go abroad. It would be different with the Ministers. I think the Prime Minister must be getting quite tired of Cameron Highlands. The Federal passport does not benefit the vast majority of our people one wee bit. It is what the Chinese would describe as something good to look at but not so good to eat.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: How can you eat a passport?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Or is it the intention of the P.A.P. Government to deny passports even to Singapore citizens in future? Is it the intention to restrict still further the freedom of travel? The P.A.P. also says that being a Federal national would make the Singapore

Column: 358

citizen equal to the Federation citizen before the law and the courts. But, Sir, this is again something we already possess. So where is the additional "more"? Where is the additional gain? If this is a truly democratic society, it makes no difference whether a person is a citizen or a non-citizen, a national or a non-national, in a court of law. One would Imagine that all persons would be equal before the law in a democratic society, and not just nationals. So what is so wonderful about being a national? The only other distinction - and this is the latest development - is that a national may be called up for military service in future. The Prime Minister said that he did not want to confuse people with the new phrase called "new Federal citizen". This is sheer sophistry. If the Prime Minister did not want to cause confusion, he should not have brought in the new word "national". The fact that after becoming a Federal national the Singapore citizen still has to apply for registration to become a Federal citizen is proof enough that what the people of Singapore are getting is even worse than second-class citizenship. In fact, the P.A.P. arrangement will mean three types of citizens as far as Singapore is concerned. I shall enlarge on this later.

    This talk of citizen and national reminds me of an article I read sometime ago, which rather vividly brings out the deception and sleight of hand which is being practised by the Prime Minister. The story says the Prime Minister takes out a 20-cent piece and a 50-cent piece. He holds up the two coins showing the front face, or obverse side, to the people. And he says, "See the head of Queen Elizabeth II on the two coins. They are the same. The words on both pieces read 'Queen Elizabeth II' and therefore they are the same, and equal." That is what the Prime Minister says. But the Prime Minister also has been very cunning. He has hidden the reverse side of the coins which, if read carefully, will tell us that the coins are of different denominations. One is a 20-cent piece, the other a 50-cent piece. They are not the same, and they are not equal. So, Sir, you can see what a smart alec our Prime Minister is.

Column: 359



    There is a Chinese proverb which describes this very accurately and picturesquely. The Prime Minister, according to the proverb, wants to pass fish eyes for pearls. Does he hope thus to make everybody satisfied, everybody happy? Let me quote, Sir, the Straits Times of 25th August. He was talking to the Deputy Prime Minister of the Federation:

    '"We want to make Malaya happy and Singapore happy". And Mr Lee echoed him, "Everybody happy".'

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Except Tun Lim.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Who is "everybody"? Dare he go to the country and prove that?

    Mr Speaker: Order. The Member for Queenstown must know that I have already said in this Assembly many, many times that I do not wish to hear voices raised. He must remember that. Dr Lee.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I apologise, Sir. I shall try and control my emotions especially when I conic to those parts which tell everybody of the base treachery of the people sitting opposite.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Perhaps if the hon. Member for Queenstown remembers that he is addressing the Chair, he will not try and intimidate the Chair by raising his voice. Remember that he is addressing the Chair, and not Members opposite.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I shall bear that in mind, Sir. I would ask the Prime Minister and the not-so-expert Minister for Finance to read the Federal Constitution, Part II, pertaining to fundamental liberties. These are the rights of all persons resident in the Federation. They apply equally to citizens and non-citizens. Most of these rights apply even to enemy aliens. In fact, Article 8 of the Federal Constitution states - I will quote, Sir:

    '8 (1).-All persons are equal before the law and entitled to the equal protection of the law.'

Column: 360



    Mr David Marshall (Anson): Point of order, Mr Speaker, Sir. The very next subsection makes a very vital distinction. I would ask him to read it to this House - there is a vast distinction where only citizens are protected.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I will read that second subsection as well.

    '(2).-Except as expressly authorised by this Constitution, there shall be no discrimination [no discrimination] against citizens on the ground only of religion, race, descent or place of birth in any law or in the appointment to any office or employment under a public authority or in the administration of any law relating to the acquisition, holding or disposition of property or the establishing or carrying on of any trade, business, profession, vocation or employment.'

For me, Sir, the relevant portion, to a not-so-legal-minded doctor, is the first one. And you will note, Sir, it does not say all citizens but all persons, i.e. whether they are citizens or non-citizens. So what does this equality before the courts mean to the ordinary man in the street? It means that before he can become recognised as an equal under the P.A.P. merger, he must first be arrested and brought to court. Sir, we -

    The Minister for Health and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): What is all this about? I do not -

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Only people like the Minister for Health and Law who expect to be arrested sometime or other -

    Mr Byrne: By whom?

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - will find the the need for such protection. The rest of us, who are all peace-loving and law-abiding citizens and who will never have the misfortune to be brought to a court of law, do not want such equality. We want equality, not just inside the court but outside the court as well. That is what we mean by "equality". The concept of Federal national could have very little meaning and significance within the Federation. What really counts in the Federation is citizenship, and there

Column: 361

would at least be two types of citizenship under the P.A.P.'s type of merger, i.e. a Federal and a Singapore citizenship.

    The Singapore citizen, under such an arrangement as we are told, will only be able to vote in Singapore. The Federal citizen, on the other hand, will vote in the Federation. In other words, a Singapore citizen who goes to the Federation after this so-called merger will automatically become disenfranchised. What sort of a merger is this when a citizen of one part in one identity is treated like an alien when he steps into the other part in the same identity? What sort of a unification of our people is this, when Singapore citizens will possess separate citizenship rights and will not be able to share a common political life and destiny with the citizens in the Federation? Under the P.A.P.'s so-called merger, without this common political life and destiny with the people of the Federation, the people of Singapore will not be able to give expression to and obtain redress for their grievances and aspirations through the normal democratic channels.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I do not know whether the Member for Queenstown does realise that he has been repeating that sentiment time and time again. I know it is difficult perhaps when dealing with three motions at the same time, but he must so reorientate his speech that there should not be any repetition as far as it can be helped. We have a Standing Order which is aimed at trying to cut the debate short. I had better read that Standing Order for the benefit of all Members:

    '54. The Speaker or the Chairman, after having drawn attention to the conduct of a Member, who persists in irrelevance, or tedious repetition either of his own arguments or of the arguments used by other Members in debate, may direct him to discontinue his speech.'

But I will not say that the repetition up to now has reached the stage of being tedious. Anyway, I think that Standing Order should be borne in mind by all Members of the Assembly when they make their speeches. Dr Lee.

Column: 362



    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, it is unavoidable that there must be some repetition in places, because facts have to be brought out at every stage to prove certain points; and if they are not brought out again, then the whole relevance and the whole emphasis is lost. You will appreciate my difficulty, Sir, and I understand your impatience too about that.

    I was saying, Sir, that while the people in the Federation can interfere with the affairs of the people of Singapore, through the Federation Government, the people of Singapore will not have the full democratic right to inform and influence the people of the Federation. The only contact we will have with the people in the Federation under such a treacherous arrangement will be through the few token representatives from Singapore in the Federation legislature. Under this phoney merger with separate citizenship, the people of Singapore will be kept politically isolated from the people of the Federation. We in Singapore will be treated as though we are suffering from some infectious disease that requires us to be permanently segregated from the people of the Federation, because we will not possess Federation citizenship under this phoney merger. All Singaporeans who do not see eye to eye with the Federation Government can be conveniently prevented from crossing the Causeway. Already, Sir, we have an outstanding example almost staring us in the face. The Federation Government has debarred permanently one Inche Said Zahari, prominent Malay citizen of Singapore and a former editor of the Utusan Melayu, from entering the Federation. The Prime Minister touched on Said Zahari's case only a couple of days ago. Inche Said Zahari, Sir -

    Mr Speaker: I cannot allow the Member for Queenstown to go into the details of that case. It has nothing to do with this particular problem we are discussing. He can just mention it in passing as illustrative of an allegation he has made. But I do not think he should go into details.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I am not going into details, Sir. I just want to bring out the point, Sir, that although Inche Said

Column: 363

Zahari is a son of the soil, but just because he happens to hold different political views - views different from those held by the politicians who are in power in the Federation - he has, therefore, been debarred from entering the Federation.

    Mr Speaker: Order. The hon. Member must not make statements like that unless he can substantiate them. If he can do so, then, of course, he is entitled to make that statement. If he cannot substantiate it, then he might find himself guilty of abuse of privilege.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Anyway. Sir, that proves the point, that people from Singapore can be prevented from going into the Federation. Under these circumstances, how can anyone say that there is a bringing-together of the peoples of the two territories? What sort of merger then is this? It is like telling the people, say, of Mountbatten constituency or Farrer Park constituency that they are not fit to share a common citizenship with the rest of the people of Singapore; that they must have a separate citizenship; that they can vote and stand for election only in their own constituencies; that they cannot come out and campaign outside their own constituencies; and that if they wish to vote outside their own constituencies they must re-apply all over again for the citizenship right possessed by the rest of the people of Singapore. I am sure the Member for Farrer Park and the Member for Mount-batten will not relish things like this. How would the people of Mountbatten feel if they were to be treated like this? But this is precisely how the people of Singapore will be treated if the P.A.P.'s phoney merger is pushed through. They will be treated as second-rate citizens. First segregated, then devitalised and throttled. In fact, the Prime Minister's merger amounts to this. All the people of Malaya, including Singapore, will belong to one club, the Federal National Club. This club is only a show-case to the outside world, a pretence that the people of Malaya and Singapore are united as one. But, within this club is another more important and privileged club, the Federal Citizens Club, in which

Column: 364

all the citizens of the present eleven States of the Federation will be Members, but from which Singapore citizens will be completely excluded. We will be treated like social outcastes, not fit and not allowed to mix freely as equals with our Federation brothers across the Causeway. This exclusive snobbish club is reminiscent of the exclusive Tanglin Club which the Prime Minister was so fond of ridiculing in his former anti-colonial days. The Tunku is prepared to throw open the doors of this exclusive Federal Citizens Club also to the citizens of the three Borneo territories. But he is not prepared to open its doors to the citizens of Singapore. On 26th October, 1961, the Tunku said in the Federal Parliament debate on merger - I quote here, Sir, from the Straits Times of 17th October:

    'All the states in Malaysia would enjoy equal rights and equal status. But because of the special position of Singapore as a City state, to my mind, it would be best if Singapore came in on a partnership basis.'

And when elaborating on what he meant by Malaysia, the Tunku said:

    'What I have in mind is to call such an association or Federation of states the Federation of Malaysia, that is, all the Federation of Malaya states, the Borneo territories and Singapore, in which the states of Borneo territories and the states of the Federation of Malaya join in together as Federation of Malaysia and Singapore is joined in partnership -'

    Mr David Marshall rose -

    Mr Speaker: Is it a point of order?

    Mr David Marshall: It is a point of order, Sir. Could the Member finish the sentence? It is important, Sir.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: "in partnership" - I will just follow from there, Sir.

    '... on a footing something like that which exists between the United Kingdom and Northern Ireland.'

Sir, from all indications so far, we can say that this partnership is going to be a very unequal partnership. The Federation of Malaya wants to take the Borneo territories as the 12th, 13th, and 14th States of the Federation. But Singapore will not form the extra 15th or 12th if you like, State of the Federation. Singapore will only go in as a partner,

Column: 365

In other words, the Borneo territories will truly be integrated with the Federation of Malaya to form the Federation of Malaysia. But Singapore will be kept away. Why?

    Dato Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat (Geylang Serai): Too many Communists.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Why have we to be segregated instead? Has the Member for Geylang Serai small-pox, or have all the people of Singapore smallpox? Are we going in as an equal constituent unit of the Federation? No. Are we having a merger of the peoples? No. And are we, under the so-called socialists on the other side, Sir, expediting the progress of socialism in Malaya? Again, no. Yet, all along, the P.A.P. has been saying that the present constitutional arrangement is merger. In fact, the Federation may be likened to a man getting ready to take on a first, a second and a third wife. These three wives are the three States in the Borneo territories. All the children, that is, the citizens, are legitimate children with equal rights to the family estate and to the use of family property, namely, Federation citizenship. But Singapore is going to be taken in not as a fourth wife but only as a mistress, and all the children of this mistress are going to be treated as illegitimate children with no rights to the family estate or to the use of family property, that is Federation citizenship. Poor Singapore citizens! They are all going to be treated like bastards, illegitimate children with no Federal citizenship rights.

    The Acting Prime Minister in his letter to the Opposition Leaders on 6-9-61 says - I will quote, Sir.

    This is the letter from the Deputy Prime Minister to me as Chairman of the Barisan Sosialis. The relevant words are here, Sir:

    'The only difference between Singapore and any one of the other States in the Federation is that there will be more powers reserved to the Singapore State Government.'

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: That is correct.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Is this true, Sir?

Column: 366



    Dr Toh Chin Chye: That is correct. These are the heads of agreement.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: No. Is Singapore, just like Johore or Selangor, really a part of the Federation? No. Can a person from Singapore stand for election in Kuala Lumpur for example, just like a person from Ipoh or Seremban? No. Is there complete freedom of travel between Singapore and the Federation just as amongst other States in the Federation? Again no. Then why did the Acting Prime Minister deliberately mislead us? Why the deliberate misrepresentation? Why this game of bluff? Dr Toh says -

    Dr Toh Chin Chye rose -

    Mr Speaker: On a point of order?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Yes, Sir. He has just quoted me from a letter and the relevant portion has been read out. Now, he has used that little paragraph to misconstrue what I said in there, and that I intended to mislead him. I think there is provision under the Standing Orders that no imputation should be made against a Member.

    Mr Speaker: I cannot see any imputation up to this stage. But if the point is that other parts of the letter would throw a little more light on the subject, then I think the Member for Queenstown should read the whole letter. Perhaps he should read the whole letter and we will see whether there will be any more light shed on the topic.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: If you would like me to read the whole letter. I could. Sir, but I do not think -

    Mr Speaker: Please do.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Here is the letter from the Acting Prime Minister, Singapore, dated 6th September, 1961, addressed to Dr Lee Siew Choh, Chairman, Barisan Sosialis. Singapore. 

'Dear Dr Lee,



 I  have  received replies to my letter  of  the  26th

August  from  leaders  of the four  political  Parties

represented  in  the Legislative Assembly.  I  enclose

herewith copies of their replies for your reference. I

must  point out that my letter of the 26th August  was

prompted by


Column: 367

the statements made in the Press by Opposition Party leaders, some asking for an All-Party conference in order that their views may he heard. If an All-Party conference is to he of value to assist and guide the Government in its deliberations on the constitutional arrangements for merger, there must be unanimity on the main points. It is clear from the replies that there is no agreement on the main points among the political Parties in the Opposition, although all are forced by circumstances and the pressure of public opinion to pay lip service to the principle of merger.

    I had raised two points upon which I sought explicit clarification of the stand of cacti political Party. Do you agree that in the merger arrangements (1) Defence, External Affairs and Security come under the control of the Central Government? (Point considered basic by the Federation). (2) Singapore should retain autonomy on Education and Labour? (Point considered essential by the Singapore Government). In none of the replies is there any answer to these two points. All Parties have chosen to evade these two points.

    The respective stands of the four political Parties in the Assembly are as follows:

    (a) Barisan Sosialis stand for complete merger as a 12th State on the basis of Penang and Malacca.

    Its second preference is for confederation between Singapore and the Federation and the three Borneo territories in which Defence and External Affairs excluding Security go to the Central Government. Security is to remain a subject for local autonomy.

    (b) Alliance of S.P.A., U.M.N.O., M.C.A.. M.I.C gives no answer, but raises a query as to whether the arrangements amount to a merger or a confederation.

    (c) United People's Party stand for complete merger as a State of the Federation.

    (d) Workers' Party wholeheartedly believes in merger with the Federation and considers confederation a very valuable concept.

    I must point out that complete merger means that both point (1) External Affairs and Security and point (2) Education and labour will all be under the control of the Central Government. Since most Opposition Party leaders in the Assembly propose complete merger as their first objective, if I get a categorical assurance from Opposition Political Parties that they will ask their followers to support complete merger, the Government is prepared to put forward complete merger as an alternative basis for negotiations between Singapore and the Federation.

    The P.A.P. believes that it represents the wishes of the majority of people in Singapore in insisting that Education and Labour should he under local autonomy. However,

Column: 368

we are prepared to follow the will of the people, if it is the majority wish that Education and Labour should also be under Central Government control.

    May I point out that 42 out of the 51 Assemblymen today were elected in 1959 on a P.A.P. ticket. Of these 42, 16 have broken away - 13 now in the Barisan Sosialis and three in the United People's Party. All P.A.P. candidates who contested the 1959 general elections signed a pledge in April 1959 in which they categorically pledged to support the policy of merger between the Federation and Singapore as set out in the Central Executive Committee statement published in the 1958 Fourth Anniversary Souvenir number."

    Then with quotations. Do I read all this also, Sir?

    Mr Speaker: I think the point that the Leader of the House was making is that the quotation taken out of context might not indicate what is its real meaning. Perhaps if the hon. Member - I do not know whether this is another lengthy -

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: It is a very lengthy quotation.

    Mr Speaker: Perhaps if the hon. Member will come to the relevant passage from where his quotation came.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: The only relevant part was the part I quoted, Sir. Well, this is more or less relevant. I will read this part - a small part will do.

    'In order to clarify the position, may I briefly explain [this is Dr Toh's letter] that the arrangements between Singapore and the Federation are those of a merger as a State of the Federation. They do not constitute a confederation. A confederation is an association of independent States and no citizens of a constituent State vote for representatives direct to the central confederation government.

    Our arrangements amount to merger because the people of Singapore will be voting representatives direct into the Federal Parliament. The only difference [these are the words I used, Sir] between Singapore and any one of the other States in the Federation is that there will be more powers reserved to the Singapore State Government.'

    That is good enough already, Sir.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: That is quite correct, is it not?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Correct? I do not have to read some more.

Column: 369



    Having heard all that, Sir, when We all know the present state is entirely different from what the Deputy Prime Minister has been trying to make us believe, can we ask the Deputy Prime Minister whether he thinks he can fool the people all the time?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: I do not want to fool anybody.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Under those circumstances, Sir, are we not justified in calling the Deputy Prime Minister - I would like to use the word, Sir, but -

    An hon. Member: Do not use it!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - a liar. That is the word, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Order. The Member for Queenstown must not be deliberately unparliamentary and then hope that the Speaker will just ask him to withdraw that word and not take any further action. I will not allow any deliberate use of any unparliamentary word. That is a deliberate use of an unparliamentary word and an attempt has been made to disguise it.
